 O well, the reason I left this post was to question the statement repeated by a few in the thread "All life came from a common ancestor."
 
 All known life works basically along the same mechanism. There are cells with fatty membranes to separate the metabolism from the surroundings. There is a DNA-RNA based genetic mechanism. There are always polypeptides and proteins with variations on the same basic structure type. This would lead us to think that since all life shares these things there must have been at some point one organism with all these things present and it is the one common ancestor. 
 
 But it didn't have to be. There could have been several pre-organisms (protocells) that had just crossed the threshold from pre-life to living with different variations on the DNA-RNA-lipid-protein theme. These could have competed and/or cooperated to form new organisms with some parts from over here and some parts from over there. There could have been a whole class of these types of proto-organisms that led to different types of similar (but not the same) organisms whose progeny could be traced forward to organisms living today. I think it would be a more basic form of convergent evolution.
 
 I'm just saying that it's not utterly necessary for there to be a single common ancestor. Of course, I'm probably wrong. emoticon_rolleyes
